repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: This PR uses cythonize() in pyximport. Closes #2304.

comment_data.body:
This can be simplified.
```suggestion
    user_options = _build_ext.user_options + [
        ('c-build-dir=', None, "directory for generated c files"),
    ]
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,13 +12,25 @@
 
 
 class new_build_ext(_build_ext, object):
+
+    user_options = _build_ext.user_options[:]
+
+    user_options.extend([
+        ('c-build-dir=', None, "directory for generated c files"),
+    ])

comment_data.body: I guess this is meant to turn an absolute path into a relative path with the same directory names. Can't say right now if this always works in a cross-platform way. What about Windows network drives, for example? (`\\server\path`)
I'd rather have this depend on `blocked_modules`.

Compiling .pyx sourcecode is failing only due `distutils.extension` module:

```
ImportError: Building module calc_pi failed: ["TypeError: pattern is not of type str nor subclass of Extension (<class 'distutils.extension.Extension'>) but of type <class 'distutils.extension.Extension'> and class <class 'distutils.extension.Extension'>\n"]
```

Do you want just to add this module to the `blocked_modules`? Or you want to include there **all** distutils modules? (this can be pretty dirty since distutils contains **a lot** of modules)
I have added `os.path.splitdrive()` to remove windows/network drive. This should cover all cases.

I think it would seem reasonable to interpret entries in `blocked_modules` as "blocked modules and their subpackages".
The disadvantage is that then there's no easy way to actually get a module in such a subpackage compiled.
Maybe there could be a `blocked_packages` for the wider use case?
Good idea. I have introduced blocked_packages and checked use it for check.

I'd suggest making this `static` to avoid "leaking" symbols.
```suggestion
static int test_value = 5;
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,35 @@
+
+PYTHON -c "import basic_test; basic_test.test()"
+
+######## basic_test.py ########
+
+import os.path
+import pyximport
+
+pyximport.install(build_dir=os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), "TEST_TMP"))
+
+def test():
+    import mymodule
+    assert mymodule.test_string == "TEST"
+    assert mymodule.header_value == 5
+    assert not mymodule.__file__.rstrip('oc').endswith('.py'), mymodule.__file__
+
+######## mymodule.pyxbld ########
+
+def make_ext(modname, pyxfilename):
+    from distutils.extension import Extension
+    return Extension(name = modname,
+                     sources=[pyxfilename],
+                     include_dirs=['./headers'] )
+
+######## mymodule.pyx ########
+
+cdef extern from "myheader.h":
+    int test_value
+
+header_value = test_value
+test_string = "TEST"
+
+######## headers/myheader.h ########
+
+int test_value = 5;

comment_data.body:
Hmm, right. `old_build_ext` doesn't seem to have such an option. But it does have a `cython-c-in-temp` option.

In any case, we shouldn't invent something new here. I think `new_build_ext` was more intended to grab its configuration from directives. Not sure right now what the intended way to provide `Options` options for it…

comment_data.body:
I tried slightly different approach. It requires more changes in `new_build_ext` but:
1. I am able to remove `c-build-dir` parameter
2. I have added new parameter `cython-c-in-temp` but as said it is already in `old_build_ext` and fixing #3541 requires adding it to `new_build_ext` anyways.
3. with this change we can also close #2071 for free by merging this PR!!
4. I personally like more moving `cythonize()` to `build_extension()` since it make more sense (cythonizing source codes is part of building not options handling)

Downside of this change is that it is more invasive. @scoder please let me know what do you think about it.

EDIT: And most prominent feature of it is that it breaks totally CI (joking) :-/
EDIT2: break of CI is caused by setuptools which adjusts extension in `finalize_options()` which enforces that extension cannot be changed afterwards. This makes last commit broken for setuptools. Hence I am not sure whether it is good approach to cythonize in build stage afterwards (which I don't like to be honest :-( )
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,13 +12,23 @@
 
 
 class new_build_ext(_build_ext, object):
+
+    user_options = _build_ext.user_options + [
+        ('c-build-dir=', None, "directory for generated c files"),

comment_data.body:
The problem is following which I am struggling right now:

`cythonize()` call needs to have build dir in order to know where `.c` file should be put. When `cythonize()` is placed in `finalize_options()` I am not able to get this information other than providing it via option (`c-build-dir`). When I put `cythonize()` in `build_extension()` I have build dir location for free **but** it breaks setuptools. Hence, right now I am pretty stuck :-/

+        ('c-build-dir=', None, "directory for generated c files"),

comment_data.body:
OK I have fixed the issue by updating existing extension. I have found similar approach used already in old_build_ext.py:

https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/3748c3cd20be1e0440477b906f5c9d10a0afd254/Cython/Distutils/old_build_ext.py#L197-L198
